facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 236 of 1959 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 236 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal against judgment and order dated February 24, 1956 of Nagpur High Court in Misc. Petition No. 232 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 24, 1956, of the former Nagpur High Court, in Misc. Petition No. 232 of 1954.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on May 4, 1961 by RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. May 4. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by RAGHUBAR - DAYAL, J.-This appeal, by special leave,

facts.text: High Court of Nagpur dismissed petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by special leave, is against the order of the High Court of Judicature at Nagpur, dismissing the petition of the appellant under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appellant applied to State Government, Madhya Pradesh, for prospecting licence for manganese ore over 83.18 acres, khasra No. 1 of mouza Seoni Bhondki on August 9, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On August 9, 1950, the appellant applied to the State Government, Madhya Pradesh, for the grant of a prospecting licence for manganese ore over an area of 83-1 8 acres, companyrising khasra No. 1 of mouza Seoni Bhondki.

facts.text: State Government granted prospecting licence on June 18, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government granted the prospecting licence for this area on June 18, 1951 and intimated that the prospecting licence form which was pending approval by the Union Government,

facts.text: Respondent No. 3 applied for mining lease over 32 acres out of the area on April 21, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: On April 21, 1951, respondent No. 3 applied for the grant of mining lease over 32 acres out of the aforesaid area of 83- 18 acres.

facts.text: State Government informed respondent No. 3 on October 20, 1951 that area had been granted to appellant under prospecting licence.

anchor.surface_text: On October 20, 1951, the State Government informed him that area bad been already granted to the appellant under prospecting licence, and it was number available to him.

facts.text: Respondent No. 3 applied for review to Union Government under r. 57 of Mineral Concession Rules, 1949 on November 26, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: On November 26, 1951, respondent No. 3 applied for review to the Union Government under r. 57 of the Mineral Concession Rules, 1949.

facts.text: Union Government on September 5, 1952 directed State to modify prospecting licence to 51.18 acres virgin area, as 32 acres previously held by Messrs Akbar Ali Munwar Ali.

anchor.surface_text: On September 5, 1952, the Union Government wrote to the State Government that its order regarding the grant of prospecting licence to the appellant over an area of 83-18 acres should be modified to the extent that the area granted under the prospecting licence be restricted to the virgin area of 51.18 acres, as the area of 32 acres had been previously held under a mining lease by Messrs Akbar Ali Munwar Ali

facts.text: Union Government directed 32 acres be thrown open for re-grant.

anchor.surface_text: and had number by then been thrown open for regrant. It was further directed by the Union Government, that area of 32 acres be thrown open for re-grant.

facts.text: State Government modified prospecting licence to 51.18 acres in consequence of Union direction.

anchor.surface_text: In companysequence of this direction by the Union Government, the State Government modified its order dated June 18, 1951, granting the pros- pecting licence to the appellant and restricted that licence to the virgin area of 51-18 acres only.

facts.text: Applications invited for mining lease over 32 acres some time in April 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, some time in April 1953, applications were invited for the grant of mining lease with respect to the area of 32 acres.

facts.text: Appellant submitted application for mining lease for 83.18 acres.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant submitted an application for the grant of the mining for 83-18 acres.

facts.text: Respondent No. 3 did not file any fresh application.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent No. 3  lid number file any fresh application.

facts.text: On April 30, 1954, Government granted mining lease for 51.18 acres and did not grant for 32 acres, stating granted to respondent No. 3 as directed by Union under r.57.

anchor.surface_text: On April 30, 1954, the Government granted a mining lease for manganese ore over an area of 51.18 acres and did number grant the lease for the area of 32 acres, stating in its letter to the Deputy Commissioner that area had been granted to res- pondent No. 3 tinder mining lease, as directed by the Union Government, under r. 57 of the Mineral Concession Rules.

facts.text: Appellant filed petition under Art. 226 on May 17, 1954 praying quashing of Union order granting 32 acres to respondent No. 3 and direction for entitlement to mining lease.

anchor.surface_text: Sometime thereafter, on May 17, 1954, the appellant filed the petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court, praying for the quashing of the order of the Union Government, respondent No. 2. Granting 32 acres of area in dispute to respondent No. 3, by the issue of a writ of certiorari and also for the issue of direction that the appellant was entitled to the mining lease in respect of that area.

facts.text: High Court dismissed petition holding essential to quash Union order which it could not reach.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed this petition, holding that in order to-give the relief prayed for it was essential that the order of the Union Government quashed and, as the High Court companyld number reach it, it would be incongruous to direct the State Government to ignore the order of the Union Government.

facts.text: Union Government passed order dated April 7, 1954 under r.57 cancelling State order Oct 20,1951 and directing grant of 32 acres mining lease to respondent No.3 if eligible.

anchor.surface_text: It has also been urged that the Union Government had numberjurisdiction to pass the order dated April 7, 1954, under r. 57 of the Rules when, in fact, numberapplication for- review by respondent No. 3 was pending before it, ... directing the State Government to grant a mining lease for manganese ore over an area of 32 acres to respondent No. 3, provided he was otherwise eligible.

facts.text: Review application of respondent No.3 filed Nov 26,1951 not finally disposed by Sep 5,1952 letter.

anchor.surface_text: The review application, however, Was number in fact finally disposed of by the letter from the Union Government to the State Government, dated September 5, 1952.

facts.text: Union Government never treated review proceedings as disposed of; informed respondent No.3 matter under consideration.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the several letters on record that the Union Government never treated the review proceedings before it to have been disposed of. Respondent No. 3 was informed by those letters that the matter was under companysideration.

facts.text: Review application pending on April 7, 1954 when Union passed order.

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore number companyrect to say that there was numberreview application pending with the Union Government on April 7, 1954, when it passed the order

anchor.surface_text: as the area of 32 acres had been previously held under a mining lease by Messrs Akbar Ali Munwar Ali and had number by then been thrown open for regrant.

facts.text: High Court could not quash Union Government order due to lack of territorial jurisdiction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Union Government letters confirm review pending; informed respondent matter under consideration.

holdings.text: The State Government, as urged for the appellant, has the power, under the Rules, to grant the mining lease. But its granting such a lease is subject to the orders on a review by the Union Government. Its order is final, subject to the order of the Union Government. When the Union Government directed the grant of the mining lease for an area of 32 acres to respondent No. 3, the State Government had to order such grant, in accordance with the directions of the Union Government. In fact, at that stage, the State Government only effectuates the order of the Union Government. It carries out that order which remains the final order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State grant subject to Union review under r.57; Union direction makes State order merely effectuating the final Union order.
